column1: Maidenhead is a market town in Berkshire
column2: England
column3: on the south-western bank of the River Thames. It has an estimated population of 69
column4: 309. It is part of the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead and the fourth largest town in Berkshire. Travelling by road
column5: the town is situated 30 miles (48 km) west of Charing Cross
column7: 13 miles (21 km) northeast of the county town of Reading
column10: 8 miles (13 km) south of High Wycombe and 7 miles (11 km) northwest of Windsor. The town differs from the Parliamentary constituency of Maidenhead
column11: which includes a number of outer suburbs and villages (including parts of Wokingham and Reading) such as Twyford

column1: == History ==

The antiquary John Leland claimed that the area around Maidenhead's present town centre was a small Roman settlement called Alaunodunum. He stated that it had all but disappeared by the end of the Roman occupation. Although his source is unknown
column2: there is documented and physical evidence of Roman settlement in the town. There are two well known villa sites in the town
column3: one being in the suburb of Cox Green
column4: and the other just west of the town centre on Castle Hill. This villa sat on the route of the Camlet Way which was a Roman road  linking Silchester (Calleva Atrebatum) and Colchester (Camulodunum) via St Albans (Verulamium) and passes through the present town centre. Remnants of the road have been unearthed at various locations nearby
column5: but its exact route is unclear.

column1: Maidenhead's name stems from the riverside area where the first "New wharf" or "Maiden Hythe" was built
column2: as early as Saxon times. In the year 870
column3: an army of Danes invaded the kingdom of Wessex. They disembarked from their longboats by the wharf and ferry crossing at Maidenhead and fought their way overland to Reading where they set up camp and made it their regional power base. The area of the present town centre was originally a small Anglo-Saxon town known as "South Ellington". The town would have likely developed on the Camlet Way on the site of Alaunodunum as the Bath Road was not re-routed until the 13th century. Maidenhead is recorded in the Domesday Book as the settlement of Ellington in the hundred of Beynhurst.A wooden bridge was erected across the river in about 1280 to replace the ferry in South Ellington. The Great West Road to Reading
column4: Gloucester and Bristol was diverted over the new bridge. Previously
column5: it had kept to the north bank and crossed the Thames by ford at Cookham
column7: later to become Maidenhead grew up on the site of Alaunodunum and South Ellington
column8: between the new bridge and the bottom of Castle Hill. Within a few years a new wharf was constructed next to the bridge to replace the old Saxon wharf which needed replacing. At this time
column9: the South Ellington name was dropped with the town becoming known as Maidenhythe. The earliest record of this name change is in the Bray Court manorial rolls of 1296.The new bridge and wharf led to the growth of medieval Maidenhead as a river port and market town. The present town was developed as a linear settlement in the 13th century along the newly diverted road with hostelries
column10: a guildhall and a chapel dedicated to St Mary Magdalene was built in the middle of the road. The market was held outside the old guildhall which was set back from the High Street to form the market square. Maidenhead also became the first stopping point for coaches travelling from London to Gloucester and Bath and the town became populated with numerous inns. By the mid 18th century
column11: Maidenhead was one of the busiest coaching towns in England with over ninety coaches a day passing through the town. The late 18th-century Bear Hotel on the High Street is the best of the town's old coaching inns surviving to this day.

column1: The current Maidenhead Bridge
column2: a local landmark
column3: dates from 1777 and was built at a cost of £19

column1: King Charles I met his children for the last time before his execution in 1649 at the Greyhound Inn
on the High Street
column2: the site of which is now a branch of the NatWest Bank. A plaque commemorates their meeting.

column1: When the Great Western Railway came to the town
column2: it began to expand. Muddy roads were replaced and public services were installed. The High Street began to change again
column3: and substantial Victorian red brick architecture began to appear throughout the town. Maidenhead became its own entity in 1894
column4: being split from the civil parishes of both Bray and Cookham.

column1: Maidenhead Citadel Corps of the Salvation Army was first opened in the town in the mid-1880s. Maidenhead Citadel Band was soon founded in 1886 by Bandmaster William Thomas
column2: who later became mayor of the town.

column1: By Edwardian times
column2: nearby Boulter's Lock became a favoured resort
column3: especially on Ascot Sunday
column4: and Skindles Hotel developed a reputation for illicit liaisons.

column1: == Governance ==
The town is part of the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead
column2: with an urban population of around 150
column3: 000. Currently Cllr Andrew Johnson is the Leader of the Conservative held cabinet. It was previously an independent municipal borough.

column1: The town of Maidenhead was formerly part of the Windsor and Maidenhead Parliament constituency
column2: a conservative safe seat. The Boundary Committee abolished this constituency after the 1992 general election since the electorate was growing too large
column3: splitting it into Windsor and Maidenhead.

column1: Maidenhead has been held by the Conservative Party in every election since its foundation in 1997. Theresa May was elected MP in 1997 and has represented Maidenhead ever since. As MP
column2: she took a series of ministerial positions
column3: and was appointed Prime Minister of the United Kingdom on 13 July 2016. May stood down as Prime Minister on 24 July 2019
column4: but will continue to serve as MP for Maidenhead.It is today one of the safest Conservative seats in the country
column5: with the Conservatives having a 35 percentage point lead over the second largest party (Labour) in 2017.

column1: The mayor of Windsor & Maidenhead is Councillor Sayonara Luxton (Conservative).
== Geography ==
The Maidenhead urban area includes urban and suburban regions within the bounds of the town
column2: called Maidenhead Court
column3: North Town
column4: Furze Platt (which in 2012 gained a conservation area)
column9: Fishery and Bray Wick; as well as adjoining built-up areas in surrounding civil parishes: Cox Green and Altwood in Cox Green parish
column10: Woodlands Park in White Waltham parish
column11: and part of Bray Wick in Bray parish. Bray village is linked to Maidenhead by the exclusive Fishery Estate which lies on the west bank of the Thames. To the east
column12: on the opposite side of the river from Maidenhead
column13: is the large village of Taplow in Buckinghamshire which almost adjoins the suburban village of Burnham
column15: which itself nearly adjoins the urban area of the large
column16: industrial town of Slough. To the north are the Cookhams
column18: Cookham Rise and Cookham Dean. To the west is the area of Pinkneys Green. These lie south of the Berkshire-Buckinghamshire border
column19: which is formed by the River Thames (which then bends southwards to form the Maidenhead-Taplow border). Adjoining Bray and Bray Wick to the south is the suburban village of Holyport. Continuing by road to the South-East leads to the historic
column20: royal twin towns of Windsor and Eton.

column1: Maidenhead was originally the planned western terminus for the Crossrail line (to and through London) until Reading station
column2: situated 13 miles (21 km) southwest of Maidenhead
column3: was chosen.

column1: Maidenhead lies immediately west of the Taplow ridge; a wooded spur of the Chilterns which rises dramatically above one of the most scenic stretches of the Thames. The ridge is crowned by the spectacular Cliveden House which can be seen from various parts of the town.
Maidenhead has a site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) in the northern outskirts of the town called Cannoncourt Farm Pit
column2: where the largest hand axe of the paleolithic era in Britain was discovered. The town also has a local nature reserve called The Gullet.On 12 July 1901 Maidenhead entered the UK Weather Records with the Highest 60-min total rainfall at 92 mm (3.6 in). As of July 2015
column3: this record remains.

column1: == Landmarks ==

Maidenhead clock tower was built for Queen Victoria's diamond jubilee and is located outside the railway station. Maidenhead Bridge was built in 1777. It takes the A4 over the Thames to join Maidenhead to Taplow.
All Saints' Church
column2: Boyne Hill was completed in 1857 is one of the finest examples of the early work of the architect G. E. Street. The site is also regarded by many as the premier architectural site in the town. The church
column3: consecrated on 2 December 1857 by Bishop Samuel Wilberforce
column4: became the first ecclesiastical parish in the Borough of Maidenhead.Boulter's Lock is a lock on the river Thames on the east side of Maidenhead. It adjoins Ray Mill Island.

column1: In addition the town has a range of various statues which form part of a recognisable image of the town
column2: including the 'Boy and the Boat' location at the top end of the High Street
column3: near the Methodist Church.

column1: == Character ==
Maidenhead has a long history of settlement
column2: going back to the Anglo-Saxon and Roman periods. Despite this
column3: there are no visible architectural remains in the present day town to show this.

column1: Although there are attractive residential and green areas in and around Maidenhead
column2: the historic heart of the town has been redeveloped
column3: primarily with office space
column4: high technology company headquarters and apartments
column5: making it one of the key business and commuter towns of the Silicon Corridor. This has happened in piecemeal fashion over the last forty years and unfortunately
column6: Maidenhead town centre has lost most many historic buildings and much of its traditional English market town character. The High Street and Bridge Street areas only possess one heavily restored Medieval building and a handful of Georgian buildings in the Chapel Arches area.

column1: Research by the New Economics Foundation rated Maidenhead as an example of a clone town and the town centre is regarded as in need of improvement. In December 2007
column2: the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead set up the Partnership for the Regeneration of Maidenhead (PRoM)
column3: which in October 2008 launched a comprehensive 20 Year Vision and Action Plan for rejuvenating the town centre. Launch of the plan coincided with confirmation by central government that Maidenhead will be part of the new Crossrail project. PRoM's plans highlight five key developments which will help shape the town for the future. A large new retail and residential development called 'The Landing' is due for construction shortly. Additionally there will be an upgraded railway station and transport interchange
column4: movement of the leisure centre to Braywick Park
column5: relocating the bowls club and improved links between Kidwells Park and the High Street. There are also plans to demolish the 1960s  Nicholsons shopping centre and replace it with a new retail and residential quarter built around a network of revived historic streets and a micro brewery. A new town square featuring shops
column6: restaurants and apartments is currently under construction between the central library and town hall.The Chapel Arches retail and residential development is under construction. Part of the scheme involves restoring the old Thames tributaries which run through a historic section of the town centre. The redevelopment will bring an attractive waterfront quarter with new apartments
column10: and cafes are to be a feature this new part of the town centre. The adjoining historic section of the High Street around the 18th century Chapel Arches Bridge has been restored as part of the development. Existing Georgian and Victorian buildings have been rejuvenated
column11: and the adjoining new builds have been sensitively constructed in the same historic style to bring back a sense of history and lost heritage to this part of the town centre.

column1: Maidenhead was home to the conference that agreed on the Maidenhead Locator System standard in 1980. It is located in grid square
​IO91pm.
The average house price in the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead in 2011 was £461
== Community facilities ==
Maidenhead offers High Street shopping facilities including Nicholson's Centre
column2: a shopping centre on the site of Nicholson's brewery. The town also offers an eight-screen Odeon multiplex cinema and the Magnet Leisure Centre which is scheduled to be replaced by a state of the art leisure centre. The local authority also provides a Shopmobility service
column3: where those with physical disabilities can borrow mobility scooters to navigate around the town.

column1: Maidenhead Heritage Centre and Museum was established in 1993 and moved to permanent premises in a former pub in Park Street in 2006.
In the Boyne Hill area there is Norden Farm Centre for the Arts (an arts centre including a theatre).

Waltham Place Estate on Church Hill includes an ornamental garden integrated within a 200-acre (80 ha) organic and biodynamic farm estate. It is promoted by the Campaign to Protect Rural England.The Reitlinger Open Space on Guards Club Road is named after Henry Reitlinger
column2: a leading collector of fine art. On his death in 1950
column3: the collection was vested in a trust
column4: the Henry Reitlinger Bequest. The trustees were his adopted daughter
column7: who chose to house the collection at Oldfield House
column8: now a private residence; the building dates back to 1892.The Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead has announced that a new leisure centre is to be built in the town to replace the now outdated Magnet Leisure Centre which is located east of Kidwells Park. The new facility is expected to open at the end of 2020
column9: with the council claiming there will be no break in service from the ageing Magnet Leisure Centre.The town also has various community centres
column12: located to the side of Kidwells Park near the town centre. Various activities take place here
column13: including scheduled youth drop in times as well as classes in dance provided privately in its large sports and dance studios.

column1: == Transport ==
The (Brunel-built) Great Western Main Line passes through the town
column2: calling at Maidenhead railway station and offering frequent
column3: direct services to London
column4: Reading
column7: there are less frequent direct services to Banbury
column9: Worcester and Great Malvern. It passes over Brunel's Maidenhead Railway Bridge (known locally as the Sounding Arch)
column10: famous for its flat brick arches. Maidenhead Station is the beginning of the Marlow Branch Line from Maidenhead to Marlow
column12: Furze Platt railway station on this branch also serves the northern area of Maidenhead. Rail services have been provided by Great Western since 2003-04.

column1: Local bus services are provided by First Berkshire & The Thames Valley
column2: Arriva Shires & Essex and Courtney Buses. There are also evening bus services from Slough provided by Reading Buses rather than First (as in the daytime)
column3: under the 'Thames Valley' brand

column1: The A4 runs through the town and crosses the Thames over Maidenhead Bridge. The town lies adjacent to junction 8/9 on the M4 motorway and is accessed via the A404(M) and A308(M). The A308(M)
column2: A404(M) and A404 form the Marlow and Maidenhead bypass which also acts as an important link between the M4
column3: to the south of the town
column4: and M40 at High Wycombe.

column1: The River Thames runs 1⁄2 mile (800 m) to the east of the town centre
column2: and York Stream
column3: which runs through the town centre
column4: connects to the Thames via a system of disused waterways. A renewal scheme is in progress to reopen these waterways. The Jubilee River
column5: part of the flood defence scheme

column1: The Crossrail project which is now expected to be fully opened in mid-2022
column2: after previously being expected to be completed by December 2018. In the initial plan for Crossrail
column3: Maidenhead was expected to become the terminus for the line
column4: which is now known as the Elizabeth Line. However
column5: after consultation Crossrail Limited and Transport for London decided to extend this to Reading
column6: which also serves as a major hub for the Great Western route. The route will double the current timetable from four services an hour (operated by the existing Great Western Railway route) to eight services an hour (combining both Elizabeth Line and GWR services).

column1: == Employment ==
Maidenhead is in England's Silicon Corridor along the M4 motorway west of London. Many residents commute to work in London
column2: or to the towns of Slough and Reading.

column1: Maidenhead's industries include software
column2: plastics
column3: pharmaceuticals
column4: printing and telecommunications.

column1: The town also has an office for the Department for Work and Pensions
column2: a local Jobcentre Plus which is located in Park Street. It is open 9am - 5pm Monday to Friday (10am on Wednesday) and offers help in finding employment
column3: including the National Careers Service. In addition
column4: as part of the UK Government roll out of the new social care benefit system
column5: Maidenhead is now a Universal Credit Full Service area.

column1: == Sport ==
Situated on the River Thames
column2: the town is a rowing centre. Maidenhead Rowing Club organises the Maidenhead Regatta which
column3: along with Marlow Regatta and Henley Regatta
column4: is often seen as a testing ground for olympic rowing athletes. Maidenhead has often seen winners go on to represent the United Kingdom at the Olympic games.

column1: The town's football team
column2: Maidenhead United
column3: play at York Road
column4: which is the oldest football ground in the world continuously used by the same team. Maidenhead United were crowned champions of National League South at the end of the 2016/17 season. Due to this
column5: the team were automatically promoted to the National League (fifth tier of English Football) for the 2017/18 season.

column1: The Maidenhead Rugby Club was founded in 1921 and is the largest organised sports team in the town. It consists of four men's teams
column2: a women's team and a large youth programme. The men's team attracts international talent from all over the world including American Tobin Thompson and Fijian Antinio Mawara.

column1: In September 2011 the town hosted the first ever Maidenhead Half Marathon.
The town is also home to Maidenhead Sailing Club at Summerleaze Lake which is home to one of the largest Albacore fleets in the area.
Maidenhead Golf Club was founded in 1896 and is situated close by the town centre and station in Shoppenhangers Road. The course was designed by the eminent golf architect Harry S. Colt.
FPD- A Senior social football team has played teams from the twin towns starting with a home and away leg with Bad Godesberg. Future fixtures against St-Cloud and Frascati to follow.
== Institutions ==
The local newspaper is The Maidenhead Advertiser.
Maidenhead has been the home of Maidenhead Citadel Band of the Salvation Army since 1886.
The head office of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission is based in Maidenhead on Marlow Road. Furthermore
column2: various private companies have their head offices located around the town including
column3: Johnson & Johnson
column4: the American multi-national pharmaceutical.

column1: The schools listed below consist of various types of schools including free schools and academies.

Berkshire College of Agriculture is based in Maidenhead.Although the town only has the one college

column3: including the Windsor Forest Colleges Group (formerly East Berkshire College) in both Windsor (Berkshire) and Langley
column4: Slough as well as The Henley College in Oxfordshire and Reading College (Berkshire).

== Twin towns ==
Maidenhead is twinned with:
Saint-Cloud
column2: Hauts-de-Seine
column3: France (since 1957)

column1: Bad Godesberg
column2: North Rhine-Westphalia
column3: Germany (since 1960)

column1: Frascati
column2: Lazio
column3: Italy (since 1972)

column1: Kortrijk (Courtrai) West Flanders
column2: Belgium (since 1981)Each year youths from the four towns and Berlin-Steglitz (twinned with Bad Godesberg) compete against one another in sports such as volleyball
column3: football
column4: athletics and swimming in the Twin Towns Sports Competition
column5: hosted in turn by each of the five towns. In Maidenhead town centre there are roads named after three of the twin towns (Bad Godesberg Way
column6: Frascati Way and St Cloud Way). Local schools often participate in student exchanges with pupils being exchanged between schools within the twinned towns.

column1: == Notable people and businesses ==
A number of notable figures can be counted amongst Maidenhead's current and former residents. The actress Diana Dors (1931–1984) resided for much of her life in the town
column2: in several properties
column3: while the broadcaster Richard Dimbleby (1913–1965) lived for some time on Boulter's Island. Maidenhead's riverside location has also drawn many celebrities
column4: including former broadcaster Michael Parkinson (b. 1935). The Spice Girls shared a house in Maidenhead for a year preceding their rise to stardom. In her 1988 LWT special
column6: Victoria Wood said: "The celebrities have flocked [to the studio]. I know that Maidenhead and Barnes are like ghost towns this evening."Author Hugh Lofting (1886–1947)
column8: was born in Maidenhead.Essayist and novelist Nick Hornby (b. 1957) was educated at Maidenhead Grammar School (now Desborough School)
column9: as were children's television presenter and radio show host Toby Anstis (b. 1968)
column11: athlete Mark Richardson (b. 1972) and well known "Dragon" Peter Jones (b. 1966).

column1: The film director brothers Roy (1913–2001) and John Boulting (1913–1985) were born in Bray village on the outskirts of Maidenhead in November 1913.
Professional footballer Andy King grew up in Maidenhead
column2: and attended Furze Platt Senior School. He plays for Leicester City and helped them win the Premier League title in 2016.

column1: Pinkneys Green in the town was home to Sir Nicholas Winton (1909–2015)
column2: whose heroic efforts rescued 669 Jewish children from Czechoslovakia just before the outbreak of World War II. There is a statue of him at Maidenhead Railway Station.

column1: Arthur and Ron Hacker formed the company Hacker Radio Ltd in Maidenhead in 1959
column2: producers of fine transistor radios that for a time in the 1970s brandished the Royal Warrant of Appointment

column1: The town was also home to Colonel Sir Walter de Frece (1870–1935) and Lady Matilda de Frece
column2: better known as Vesta Tilley (1864–1952).

column1: Former disabled London Marathon competitor Patrick Sheehy lived in the town for just over 3 years.
Edd China (born 1971)
column2: an English TV presenter
column3: mechanic
column4: motor specialist and inventor lives and works here.

column1: Mary Ann Browne (1812–1845) was a British poet and writer of musical scores.
